page.title: 03Captain Peel's Railway
page.content: Captain William Peel VC, a local farmer, owned land at Potton, three miles east of Sandy. Peel, in addition to his farming, was a naval captain and explorer. After the opening of the G.N.R. at Sandy, he obtained permission to build a line from Potton to connect with the G.N.R. to allow his produce to reach market more easily. He spent little time in the area because of other commitments and never saw the line in use. It was opened in 1857 whilst Peel was en route to China. He was diverted to India and contracted smallpox at the relief of Lucknow and died the next year. The line was in use for three years as an independent venture and then taken over as a part of the Bedford and Cambridge Railway, opened between those two places in 1862.
